awd_titl_txt: The Lowell Observatory Native American Astronomy Outreach Program: Completing the Kayenta Unified School District collaboration
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will fund the final year of a partnership in collaboration with 4th-8th grade teachers in the Kayenta Unified School District (KUSD), located in the Navajo Nation of northern Arizona, as part of the Lowell Observatory Navajo-Hopi Astronomy Outreach Program (NAAOP)in the 2020-2021 school year. Teachers are paired with an astronomer/educator from Lowell Observatory who regularly visits the observatory. Star parties are held in partnership with tribal educators who present traditional knowledge, and students visit Lowell Observatory as a culminating experience. In the spring of 2021, the NAAOP and the veteran KUSD teachers will hold a Navajo Nation-wide teacher workshop in order to share the curriculum and perspectives on cultural connections with others.

The project will develop, test, and revise an astronomy-centered curriculum unit for each of the 4th-8th grade levels. The curriculum uses Project Based Learning, and is aligned to Arizona, Common Core, Next Generation Science, and Navajo tribal standards. Students are kept together as a cohort over the course of the three-year collaboration, and their interest in STEM and STEM careers is assessed annually through student surveys. Results will be tallied at the end of the project and shared with stakeholders and the education and outreach communities through journals. The results of the teacher workshop will also be shared with the teaching and outreach communities, and the curriculum will be put online in a teacher-friendly package that can be downloaded.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Lowell Observatory Native American Astronomy Outreach Program (NAAOP) partnered for three school years (2018-19, 2019-20, 2020-21) with 4th-8th grade teachers in the Kayenta Unified School District (KUSD) on the Navajo Nation. We developed curriculum units for each grade that used Project Based Learning to better enable the students to see themselves as scientists. We also included local and cultural connections to the science in each unit to encourage students to see science as relevant to themselves. The purpose of these units was to increase students' interest in STEM and STEM careers.

The units also addressed Arizona state science standards, included a robotics component as well as math and reading, and required the students to create a poster of their project. The posters were presented at Lowell when the class came on their field trip, where they also engaged with Navajo engineers who came to meet the students and act as role models. To enhance the in-class activities, we held school star parties and class field trips to Lowell Observatory. We also held summer camps for rising 6th and 7th graders.

Because of COVID-19 the schools went to on-line only at the end of the second year and all of the third year of our collaboration. NAAOP figured out what activities could be done by the students at home and what could be done as demonstrations by the astronomer on-line. We sent about 500 packets of materials to the schools to distribute to the students, and worked with the teachers and the students on-line. We also held on-line summer camps and sent those students packets of materials for doing camp activities at home.

To determine the efficacy of the currciulum units in increasing the interest of students in STEM and STEM careers, NAAOP's outside evaluator designed, collected, and analyzed anonymous on-line student surveys at the beginning and end of each school year. The survey participation was lower during the COVID-affected year. Nevertheless, the evaluator reported, "Despite the limited data that were collected throughout the past three years, we still get a sense of the incredible potential of the NAAOP's new program model, the 4th-8th grade curriculum, and the summer camp offerings. ... The NAAOP program, and the partnership with Kayenta specifically, continues to have significant potential for positively impacting teachers and students in Indigenous communities."
